articles.headline: Charlie Hebdo’s Defiant Muhammad Cover Fuels Debate on Free Speech
articles.snippet: Six days after the attack on Charlie Hebdo, Muslim groups in France, Egypt and elsewhere said the newspaper’s new cover would exacerbate tensions.
articles.abstract: Six days after the attack on Charlie Hebdo, Muslim groups in France, Egypt and elsewhere said the newspaper’s new cover would exacerbate tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Immediately upon unveiling its new cover — a depiction of Muhammad — the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo on Tuesday reignited the debate pitting free speech against religious sensitivities that has embroiled Europe since 12 people were killed during an attack on its Paris offices by Muslim extremists a week ago.

articles.headline: In Malibu Luxury Home Listings, Thousands of Square Feet Often Go Missing
articles.snippet: A lawsuit between a celebrity broker and a wealthy buyer highlights a long-running tussle over what is, and isn’t, included when measuring a home’s size.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit between a celebrity broker and a wealthy buyer highlights a long-running tussle over what is, and isn’t, included when measuring a home’s size.
articles.lead_paragraph: With his close ties to Hollywood’s celebrity elite and a film-star persona, the broker Chris Cortazzo is the king of Malibu real estate.

articles.headline: Al Bendich, Defender of ‘Howl’ and Lenny Bruce’s Comedy, Is Dead at 85
articles.snippet: As a young lawyer, Mr. Bendich argued the two landmark obscenity cases, providing the legal rationales for the judge to find in favor of the defense both times.
articles.abstract: As a young lawyer, Mr. Bendich argued the two landmark obscenity cases, providing the legal rationales for the judge to find in favor of the defense both times.
articles.lead_paragraph: Al Bendich, a lawyer who successfully defended the right to free speech in two landmark midcentury obscenity cases — involving Allen Ginsberg’s poem “Howl” and Lenny Bruce’s nightclub act — died on Jan. 5 in Oakland, Calif. He was 85.

articles.headline: Study Finds Local Taxes Hit Lower Wage Earners Harder
articles.snippet: An analysis by the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy ranked states by tax burden and concluded that the poorest have the biggest burden in local taxes.
articles.abstract: An analysis by the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy ranked states by tax burden and concluded that the poorest have the biggest burden in local taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to the taxes closest to home, the less you earn, the harder you’re hit.

articles.headline: In New Congress, Wall St. Pushes to Undermine Dodd-Frank Reform
articles.snippet: The continuing assault on the 2010 Dodd-Frank law has achieved remarkable success, especially compared with the repeated failures of opponents of another 2010 law, the Affordable Care Act.
articles.abstract: The continuing assault on the 2010 Dodd-Frank law has achieved remarkable success, especially compared with the repeated failures of opponents of another 2010 law, the Affordable Care Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the span of a month, the nation’s biggest banks and investment firms have twice won passage of measures to weaken regulations intended to help lessen the risk of another financial crisis, setting their sights on narrow, arcane provisions and greasing their efforts with a surge of lobbying and campaign contributions.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: The Costs of Stinginess in Medicaid
articles.snippet: With a Republican majority in Congress looking to cut taxes and spend less, it is easy to forget that tightfisted government imposes real costs.
articles.abstract: With a Republican majority in Congress looking to cut taxes and spend less, it is easy to forget that tightfisted government imposes real costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: How much money does Arkansas save by offering stingier Medicaid than Vermont?

articles.headline: In a Safer Age, U.S. Rethinks Its ‘Tough on Crime’ System
articles.snippet: Democrats and Republicans alike are rethinking the vast, costly system of policing and incarceration that was born of a crime wave decades ago.
articles.abstract: Democrats and Republicans alike are rethinking the vast, costly system of policing and incarceration that was born of a crime wave decades ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bullets were flying in the cities. Crack wars trapped people in their homes. The year was 1994, and President Bill Clinton captured the grim national mood, declaring “gangs and drugs have taken over our streets” as he signed the most far-reaching crime bill in history.

articles.headline: Third Chance for Romney? G.O.P. Is Torn
articles.snippet: The failures of Mitt Romney’s 2012 campaign and the possibility of a Jeb Bush candidacy have many Republicans hoping there won’t be a third try in 2016.
articles.abstract: The failures of Mitt Romney’s 2012 campaign and the possibility of a Jeb Bush candidacy have many Republicans hoping there won’t be a third try in 2016.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Republicans gathered at the Oklahoma Capitol this week for the state inauguration, talk turned to Mitt Romney’s desire to pursue a third presidential bid. But a refrain quickly surfaced, even among Mr. Romney’s admirers: Don’t do it.

articles.headline: Disputed Claims Over Qaeda Role in Paris Attacks
articles.snippet: A fuller portrait of the Kouachi brothers has emerged as an international effort is focused on determining who may have been behind the attack on Charlie Hebdo, and what direct role terror organizations may have had in ordering the assault.
articles.abstract: A fuller portrait of the Kouachi brothers has emerged as an international effort is focused on determining who may have been behind the attack on Charlie Hebdo, and what direct role terror organizations may have had in ordering the assault.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The younger of the two brothers who killed 12 people in Paris last week most likely used his older brother’s passport in 2011 to travel to Yemen, where he received training and $20,000 from Al Qaeda’s affiliate there, presumably to finance attacks when he returned home to France.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Mark Mazzetti and Rukmini Callimachi

articles.headline: Bigger Settlement Said to Be Reached in Silicon Valley Antitrust Case
articles.snippet: Apple, Google, Intel and Adobe are said to be offering $415 million to settle accusations that they conspired against their own employees.
articles.abstract: Apple, Google, Intel and Adobe are said to be offering $415 million to settle accusations that they conspired against their own employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One of Silicon Valley’s most embarrassing episodes might be finally drawing to a close.

articles.headline: Christie Tells Worried Backers There Is No Hurry for 2016
articles.snippet: Gov. Chris Christie, believing that there is more than enough political money to go around, has delivered a surprising message to his top supporters and donors: Relax.
articles.abstract: Gov. Chris Christie, believing that there is more than enough political money to go around, has delivered a surprising message to his top supporters and donors: Relax.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amid the most aggressive, early and elbows-out jockeying for a presidential nomination in a generation, a contender known for his mercurial and impulsive style is delivering a surprising message to his top supporters and donors: Relax.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Michael Barbaro
